newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Britain puts "quota hoppers" before fish cuts.
newsitem.headline: Britain puts "quota hoppers" before fish cuts.

text.p: British fisheries minister Tony Baldry, dismissing a clash with his Spanish counterpart, said on Monday Britain would not implement further fleet cuts until the issue of "quota hoppers" is settled.
He added Britain would not boycott proceedings and would take an active part in negotiations on measures to protect fish stocks and ensure a long term future for the fishing industry.

"We are not prepared to contemplate any further substantial reductions in the UK fishing fleet until this whole issue of quota hopping is resolved," Baldry told a news briefing during a meeting of European Union fisheries ministers.
Baldry said that some 20 percent of the British catch quota is taken by "quota hoppers" -- mainly Spanish vessels who register under the British flag.
"It's a crazy situation that can't continue," he said, noting that Prime Minister John Major had raised the issue at a recent EU summit in Dublin reviewing the EU treaty.

Asked about an intervention by Spanish Fisheries Minister Loyola de Palacio objecting about Baldry's alleged description of Spanish fishermen as "looters," Baldry said he couldn't be held responsible for the Spanish translation.
Nor could he be responsible for the Spanish minister's "somewhat sensitive" reaction to the term "quota hoppers," he added.
De Palacio was quoted by officials as objecting to the term "quota hoppers," which implied in Spanish some form of piracy. Spanish vessels, she said, were legally flying the British flag.

The European Court of Justice recently sanctioned Britain for its action against "quota hoppers," the minister noted, a reference to its judgement last March that Britain erred in restricting the operations of foreign-owned vessels in its waters.

The Spanish minister stressed that free movement of labour and capital was one of the principles of the EU's single market and that "quota hoppers" were being discussed separately in an ongoing conference on the EU treaty.
Baldry said that national fish quotas meant there was no effective free market in fish.
